awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Accelerator and Nuclear Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the renewal of the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site hosted by Old Dominion University in partnership with Jefferson Laboratory. The site provides opportunities to ten undergraduate students each summer for ten weeks of research on topics in accelerator and nuclear physics. Students are housed at Jefferson Lab and their research projects are located there. They are part of a vibrant national laboratory community, which includes faculty and graduate students from around the world, as well as undergraduates from other summer programs. Mentors are chosen carefully for each student, based on their interests, and care is taken to ensure that each project progresses well over the course of the program. Both accelerator and nuclear physics are research areas with applications of important societal impact, including in the areas of medicine, homeland security, and energy production. By exposing undergraduates to these exciting fields, the program will increase the flow of talented students into these areas, whether that be a graduate program in accelerator science, nuclear science, or jobs in industry. 

Students can choose from experimental and theoretical projects. They develop their communication skills by presenting a talk in the eighth week and writing a final paper on their work and presenting a poster on the last day. There are two scientific/technical/professional development talks scheduled each week for the undergraduates, in addition to the many other regular activities at the lab. The students also receive training on technical writing, and each student will be mentored to present his/her results at a conference during the academic year following their summer research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT:

The REU program hosted ten students to participate in cutting edge research in accelerator and nuclear physics. The REU site is a partnership between Old Dominion University and Jefferson Laboratory; students were housed at Jefferson Lab and their research projects are located there. They were part of a vibrant national laboratory community, which includes faculty and graduate students from around the world, as well as undergraduates from other summer programs, including the DOE SULI program. Mentors were chosen carefully for each student, based on their interests, and the PIs ensured that each project progresses well over the course of the 10-week program. Students could choose from experimental and theoretical projects. They developed their communication skills by presenting a talk in the 9th week, writing a final paper on their work and presenting a poster on the last day. There were two scientific/technical/professional development talks scheduled each week for the undergraduates, in addition to the many other regular activities at the lab. The students received training on technical writing. Funding was provided for two students to extend their research into the following academic year. Each student was mentored and encouraged to present his/her results at a conference during the academic year following their summer research.

 

PROJECT OUTCOMES:
Products: During this project, there have been 11 refereed publications involving REU students as co-authors. Several more are currently in preparation for submission. There is also a large number of other, non-refereed publications (tech notes, posters, reports), presentations and talks at conferences and meetings given by REU students. We encouraged our students to submit their work to the Conference Experience for Undergraduates (CEU) program, and many of them did.

Recruiting and Diversity Statistics: Over the course of our previous cycle of four summers (2020-2023), of our 38 students, 16 were female and 6 were members of minority groups (3 students were members of both groups). Therefore, 50% of our students were members of under-represented groups.

Local Impact: During this project, we had a significant number of students from local institutions: five from ODU, one from Roanoke College, one from Washington and Lee University, one from Mary Washington, one from Christopher Newport University, one from James Madison University, one from Regent University, three from Tidewater Community College and one from J. Sargeant Reynolds Community College. During this REU cycle, 50% (19/38) of our students have been from institutions with limited options for STEM research.

 

BROADER IMPACT:

Both nuclear and accelerator physics have applications with important societal impact, including in the areas of medicine, homeland security, and energy production. Usually more than half of the undergraduate REU students in this program do projects related to accelerator science. Accelerator science is an interdisciplinary field that is not well represented at US universities, and so undergraduates are rarely exposed to it. Particle accelerators are used in many fields of scientific research and in many industrial and medical applications, yet there is a critical shortage of manpower trained in this field. By exposing these undergraduates to this exciting field, the proposed program may increase the flow of talented students into this area, whether that be a graduate program in accelerator science, or jobs in industry.

One of the goals of this program is to increase the number of students pursuing physics as a major and STEM as a career. Many of the ODU/Jefferson Lab REU students do not have the opportunity to do research at their home institution. This summer research experience made them more likely to pursue a STEM career and more knowledgeable about their options in the future. The proposed REU program emphasized recruitment of students from underrepresented groups and from local community colleges. In this way we targeted students who are at risk of abandoning a STEM career before they finish their college degree.
